acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 96 hours LC50=9.6mg/L of the fish (Fathead Minnows) (SIDS, 2005).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the guinea pig LD50 (dermal route) value of  >5,000mg/kg (SIDS (2001)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 4,390mg/kg (SIDS (2005)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible given the insufficiency of data for use in classification, along with the absence of existing classification.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 84% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=2.25 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though classified as "flammable" by ICSC (2004)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (mouse micronucleus tests), described in SIDS (2005) and NTP DB (Access on Feb., 2006). The substance showed equivocal data on mouse chromosome aberration tests which were not considered to indicate a mutagenic potential. Also, negative results were reported in in vitro mutagenicity tests (reverse mutation tests, chromosome aberration tests and mutation tests).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 518degC (ICSC, 2004)

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on no definitive evidence of reproductive/developmental toxicity at doses producing parental toxicity, described in SIDS (2005), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004) and CERI Hazard Data 98-18 (1999).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (exposure duration not presented) (SIDS (2005)): "mildly irritating," "conjunctivitis (recovery period unknown)." Also based on the description of the human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)): "reddening of the eye." The substance is thus considered a mild irritant.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the descriptions in the report on skin irritation tests in rabbits and guinea pigs (CERI Hazard Data 98-18 (1999)) (exposure duration not presented): "mild irritation," "transient hyperpigmentation and weak irritation at the site of contact." The substance is thus considered a mild skin irritant (though it is unclear whether the results are those of 4-hour application).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on the description in CERI Hazard Data 98-18 (1999) and SIDS (2005): "Skin sensitization: negative," "DMT does not induce allergic contact sensitization."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "suppression of the nervous system function, mild anemia, reticulocytosis, hypertonia, chronic inflammation of the respiratory system," "rhinitis, tracheitis, pulmonary inflammation/emphysema, degeneration of the liver and kidney" (CERI Hazard Data 98-18 (1999)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "respiratory irritation through inhalation of fumes or dusts" (CERI Hazard Data 98-18 (1999)).
